pages.title: Getting Started
pages.text: Installation Add RobBrazier/Piwik to composer.json: composer require "robbrazier/piwik=~2.1" Setup Service Provider // app/config/app.php 'providers' = array( //... RobBrazier\Piwik\PiwikServiceProvider::class, //... ); 'aliases' = array( //... 'Piwik' => RobBrazier\Piwik\Facades\Piwik::class, //... ); Publish Configuration File This will create a piwik.php config file in config/ php artisan vendor:publish --provider="RobBrazier\Piwik\PiwikServiceProvider" --tag="config"

pages.title: Laravel 4
pages.text: Installation Add RobBrazier/Piwik to composer.json: composer require "robbrazier/piwik=~2.0" Setup Service Provider // app/config/app.php 'providers' = array( //... 'RobBrazier\Piwik\PiwikServiceProvider', //... ); 'aliases' = array( //... 'Piwik' => 'RobBrazier\Piwik\Facades\Piwik', //... ); Publish Configuration File This will create a piwik.php config file in config/ php artisan vendor:publish --provider="RobBrazier\Piwik\PiwikServiceProvider"

pages.title: Usage
pages.text: There are two ways of using the Piwik Library; Using the Laravel Facade Using the app container Facade If you have added the alias for Piwik to app.php, you can use the library as follows: Piwik::method() App Container If you don't want to use the static Facade method of accessing the class, you can also do it non-statically via any of the following App/Service Container interfaces: $this->app['piwik']->method() $this->app->make('piwik')->method() App::make('piwik')->method()
